awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Multiuser Instrument for Attosecond X-Ray Probing of Correlated Quantum Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Since their discovery in 1895, x-rays have found numerous applications in medical technologies and in the elemental and structural analysis of materials and proteins. With the advent of new laser technologies, it has become possible to produce x-ray bursts of duration less than a millionth of a trillionth of a second (an attosecond). These novel ultrashort x-rays pulses can provide a window into the inner workings of complex molecules relevant to light harvesting and catalysis and guide the development of novel materials for quantum information processing. Researchers working on this project will create new x-ray research opportunities by developing an instrumental platform that integrates the x-ray pulses with state-of-the-art detectors, such as transient x-ray spectrometer and electron imaging. The goal of this effort will be direct observation, manipulation, and real-time control of quantum processes in molecules and materials, the pursuit of which is vital to energy, information, and security interests of our nation. The project will thus enhance US scientific competitiveness and train the next generation workforce in new x-ray technologies.

Specifically, the project aims to develop a tabletop instrument for time-resolved multifunctional attosecond x-ray spectroscopy, which will realize the ultimate time-resolution to probe the dynamics of charge redistribution in molecules and materials with chemical sensitivity, atomic resolution, and orbital selectivity. The instrument will cover the soft x-ray range from 100 to 1000 electron volts using a high-power mid-infrared laser for harmonic generation. The combination of attosecond resolution, high flux, and elemental specificity will extend the x-ray spectroscopic capabilities into a new regime, leading to a unique multiuser instrument for novel insights into fundamental electronic processes, especially those involving correlated electron dynamics. The instrument will offer easy access and research training opportunities for students and early career researchers. The development project integrates transient x-ray absorption spectroscopy, photoelectron spectroscopy, streaking capabilities, and coincident charge particle imaging to serve a broad user base at the University of Arizona, as well as other scientists at the national level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
By virtue of their high frequency, x-rays can penetrate inside materials, which form the basis for their application in biological imaging, materials characterization, and structural probing of proteins and other biomolecules. New applications open when the x-rays are confined to short pulses lasting attoseconds (billionths of a billionth of a second). Such x-ray pulses act as an x-ray camera flash to strobe the ultrafast motion of electrons that govern the physical and chemical properties of substances. Specifically, we apply such x-ray pulses to conduct attosecond spectroscopy, which allows us to track the real-time dynamics of electrons in molecules and materials.

In this instrumentation project, we developed the optical and x-ray beamlines as well as detection systems such as photon and electron spectrometers to capture the ephemeral states of chemical systems. We set up the vacuum chambers and built a high-harmonic generation source. We employed the extreme non-linearity of noble gases to upconvert the frequency of the laser to the x-ray regime. Specialized optical components were installed in the chambers to convey the x-ray pulses from the source to the interaction chamber. The equipment was assembled and interfaced with the laser systems to conduct time-resolved pump-probe spectroscopy. In this scheme, one ultrashort infrared or visible pulse is used to excite the molecules, which are then probed with another ultrashort x-ray pulse. We used optomechanical components such as motorized stages and precision manipulators to direct the optical and x-ray beams to ensure proper focusing and exact spatial and temporal matching of pump and probe pulses.

One of the diagnostic systems developed in this project is termed attosecond transient absorption. This approach tracks electronic motion in molecules through ultrafast changes in absorption, using elementally or chemically specific transitions that serve to fingerprint the transient state of the chemical system. A grating spectrometer that covers the energy range from extreme ultraviolet to soft x-rays was installed to conduct these studies. In preliminary experiments, we applied this instrumentation for attosecond transient absorption experiments in atoms and polyatomic molecules such as neon, argon, methyl iodide, and iodobenzene. We also applied optical and x-ray spectroscopy approaches to study electron and phonon dynamics in materials. Another detection approach we developed for this project relies on the study of charged particles emitted in the photon-molecule interaction. Specifically, we set up a high-resolution time-of-flight detector and designed a velocity map imaging setup. These detectors allow us to characterize the energy and momentum of electrons and ions emitted from the interaction region. Using this information, we can study the electronic wavepacket dynamics and the impact of nuclear motion on such dynamics.

A vital outcome of this project was the training of graduate students in the construction and operation of state-of-the-art instrumentation. These students will form the next generation workforce in the frontier areas of ultrafast spectroscopy, optical design, laser science, x-ray imaging, semiconductor lithography, among others. Valuable professional development opportunities were created for postdocs, graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students. Under this project, we disseminated our results through publications, talks, conference presentations, and other avenues. Participants also conducted scientific outreach activities involving students from local schools, visitors, and the local community. The far-reaching impacts of this project are the application of new instrumentation to study the inner workings of complex molecules relevant to light harvesting and catalysis and guide the development of novel materials for quantum information processing—topics that are essential to the scientific progress of the nation.
